all_paragraphs: Across the internet, you can easily find articles on interview tips for data science or machine learning roles.
Most of these articles cover the standard points that will potentially put you on equal footing within most candidate pools.

But within the machine learning industry, there’s a high supply of data scientists and machine learning engineers to go with the increase in demand for machine learning practitioners within the industry.
So it’s going to take more than the average interview tips to ensure you stand out from the crowd.
These tips are derived from my interview experience when applying for Computer Vision Engineer and Data Science roles in London, United Kingdom.
On that note, let’s get into the five unconventional tips for your next interview.

Machine Learning topics are highly technical and straight forward when discussed. What I mean is that when questions are asked, there tends to be little to no ambiguity to answers that could be given.
You either know what you are talking about or you don’t.

In some interview scenarios, there’s little to no room to have an extended discussion around ML topics, especially when an interview feels like an interrogation with the several “What is” and “How Do I” type questions.
There’s nothing wrong with having direct answers when asked questions such as “What is a neural network” or “How do you prevent a network from overfitting”.
Although, direct answers can showcase your knowledge and in some cases, expertise; they fail to showcase your personality, experience and creativity.
Well prepared interviewers have other questions or methods of gauging your personality and other social factors.
But for those who don’t, you might come across as typical or nothing out of the ordinary.
One approach that has worked for me is having a conversation around a topic that’s asked within questions.
To give an example of how you can initiate conversations around interview questions, take a look at the two scenarios described.
Interviewer: Could you explain what overfitting is and how you would prevent it?

Candidate 1: Overfitting occurs when the machine learning model does not generalise accurately to unseen data. This usually happens when the model learns predominantly patterns, including noise, that are present within the training data. Overfitting is fixed by reducing the number of features in the training data or reducing the complexity of the network through various regularisation techniques.
Interviewer: Could you explain what overfitting is and how you would prevent it?

Candidate 2: Overfitting occurs when the machine learning model does not generalise accurately to unseen data. This usually happens when the model learns predominantly patterns, including noise, that are present within the training data. Overfitting is fixed by reducing the number of features in the training data or reducing the complexity of the network through various regularisation techniques.
Could I ask, What methods to prevent overfitting do data scientists within your team leverage?
The two scenarios described above are very similar, and if you read to quickly, you might have missed the difference between both answers from the candidates.
Candidate 1 answered the question well, and the answer given was relatively detailed.
But, the majority of candidates(not all) taking an interview are very prepared to answer typical ML/DS science such as the one asked above.
My point is, there is nothing that differentiates candidate 1 from the other candidates that could have answered the question as well.
Candidate 2, on the other hand, has posed a question back to the interviewer on the same subject matter, creating an opportunity for a conversation around the topic.
This allows the interviewer to go off-script and ask the more exciting and non-scripted question.

More importantly, ending answers to a question asked by the interviewer with a related question portrays to the interviewer that you are curious and interested in the operations of the team/company already.
I use this technique to break out of an interrogation style interview and move more to a natural feeling conversational interview, where both parties are comfortable.
Remember that interviewers hire people they like.
Having a conversational style interview enables your personality to come across in a more likeable manner.
Don’t take physical flashcards into the interview, please.
Nerves got the best of me during my first interview. I stumbled on my words which lead to me losing my train of thought when answering questions.
Some people have good composure within interview environments without even having to think. These individuals work well under pressure.
Unfortunately, I’m not one of those individuals.
Once during an interview, I was asked to describe the processes by which I would detect particles that represented fish food in a tank of small fishes. The role was within the agriculture industry.
I knew the task to be solved was object detection, and I was familiar with the processes involved in solving typical machine learning tasks.
But when answering the question, I skipped some processes due to nervousness.
When I try to rectify earlier mistakes when giving my answers, it made the whole answer delivery unstructured and unrehearsed.
I didn’t suffer from stage fright, and I understood the question that was asked of me; I simply had brain farts, and at times I found I was suddenly absent-minded.
These things happen when candidates become anxious, pressured and stressed.
One method I found that reduced my level of anxiety was having flashcards on topics I was sure I was speaking on.
These could be flashcards mentioning talking points on key techniques, algorithms or projects I’ve worked on.

I typically went over these flashcards on my commute to the interview, and I found my nerves reduced, and these talking points were at the forefront of my thoughts and ready to be delivered when required.
Here are some flashcards apps I used during my studies and interview preparations: Ankiapp and Brainscape.
You could also use a standard note-taking app on your phone.
The point is to have a method of on-demand recollection on your fingertips.
Here is a great article that touches on other strategies to reduce nerves during interviews.
An interview is for you as well as the employer.
Understanding of psychology is a superpower that can also be useful in interview scenarios.
Typically interviewers ask candidates the question ‘Why do you want to work with our company?’.
This is a fair question, but I want you to realise that an interview not only determines if a candidate can work within a company.
During an interview, you can get an intuition on if a company is good enough for you.
An interview is a process with bi-directional feedback, where two parties have to make a decision, a realisation we seem to forget as interviewees.
So, don’t be afraid to reverse the roles.

For example, try asking an interviewer questions towards the end of a good interview such as ‘Why does your company want to hire someone like me?’ or ‘Why do you think I would be a good fit within your company?’.
Doing this easily reverses the role and turns you into the interviewer.
What is the benefit of role reversal?

If your interview has been successful so far, then an interviewer feedbacking to you an answer as to why you would be a good fit within a company reaffirms to the interviewer the reasons as to why they should choose you over the rest of the candidates.
You can almost think of it as double down on your positive qualities within the mind of the interviewer.
Ohh, I think it goes without saying that this technique will not work after a bad interview.

Machine Learning Engineering and Data Science roles are typically cross-functional, meaning that they involve collaborating and working with other team members that do not necessarily have machine learning associated roles or knowledge.
Employers typically gauge an extent of a candidates collaborativeness and willingness to work within teams in some form or manner during the interview.
Commonly, if you make it to the later stages of an interview process, you are introduced to team members that you could be working with or even management teams that are vital project stakeholders.
The point is, not everyone you speak to during your interview process will speak AI or code. I’m indicating that they might not have a clue of the technical jargon you use during discussions.
Currently, I work with app designers and developers, and I don’t expect them to understand why the performance of an object detection model might degrade under bad lightings or darker environment.

But it is my responsibility to be able to communicate areas involved in my domain in layman terms so that non-technical team members can understand the reasons behind decisions or technological limitations.
Having the skill and intuition to realise when to switch between detailed and simple explanations is a bonus skill interviewers and employers will appreciate within candidates and potential hires.

One tip I would suggest cultivating this skills is to practise mock interviews with individuals with minimal to no knowledge on the machine learning domain and try to explain terms and terminologies to a level where they come out with a decent understanding.
Before you start attending Data Science interviews, why not write at least three articles that are published on the biggest Data Science publication on Medium.
Publishing articles on Medium is not a standard interview tip, but hear me out.
Machine Learning is a broad field that encompasses several disciplines, algorithms, techniques, and more.
Several talking points are available for ML practitioners to pick and write an article on.
When applying for computer vision roles in late 2019, I wrote articles explaining several topics associated with computer vision and deep learning.
I had written more than five articles before my first interview.

All of these benefits are not unique to me and even you can realise these benefits if you begin writing today and remain consistent.
Just remember to keep writing, even after getting a machine learning role.

There are a large number of articles on the internet you can read that will help you prepare for data science interviews, but very little of them touch on the psychological and social aspects of taking an interview. The main focus tends to be technical, and that’s fair.
Like I alluded earlier to in this article, to not be an ordinary job candidate, we have to take extraordinary steps to stand out from the crowd.
Supplementing the information provided in this article with your typical technical interview tips and advice will place you in a strong position within many candidate pools.
